title: In age of technology, teachers need to return to classrooms: Experts - Channel News Asia
text:
A 
From chalkboards to smart boards, education is changing as younger generations are growing up with smartphones, tablets and laptops. 
The ease of access to information via technology is transforming the way classrooms are being conducted and educators need to learn to teach with it, said a panel of industry experts on Channel NewsAsia's Perspectives, which aired on Sep 2. 
“We pretty much have access to a lot of information, so how do we make sure all of this is usable?” asked Professor Tan Eng Chye, Deputy President of Academic Affairs and Provost, National University of Singapore, as he addressed the importance of teaching students how to make sense of information obtained through the internet. 
“We still feel that teachers play a very important role, but this role has to change over time, we have to be very responsive,” he said. 
A NEW AGE OF TEACHING 
Topics surrounding the future of education were discussed on the panel show, titled “Schools in the Cloud? Globalisation, Innovation and the Future of Learning”, held at University Hall at the National University of Singapore (NUS) on Aug 17. 
According to Prof Tan, teachers need to guide their students to adapt to the future of learning. 
“It is very important for individuals to be able to curate this information, to have a really good scaffolding to understand where it stands in this network of knowledge and how you can use it.” 
Others experts on the panel include David Edwards, Head of Education, GEMS World Academy Singapore; Stephanie Hung, Senior Director, Public Sector Group, Microsoft Singapore; and Dr Richard Yen, Founder and Managing Director, Ednovation. The Perspectives panel, led by moderator Teymoor Nabili, put forward to industry experts if the education system is helping students and the workforce of today to be future ready. 
IGNITING PASSION 
Mr Edwards said student-teacher interactions in classrooms are now different, where the teacher is no longer the “purveyor of all information”. 
“The importance of the teacher (today) is to ignite the passion, to be an example of life-long learning, to be a mentor and a guide for that learning is even more important now than ever,” said Mr Edwards. 
Dr Yen, who runs a company that supplies e-curricula to preschools in Singapore, South-East Asia and China, said that the role of teachers is to kindle passion in learners. 
“Once you have that passion, with technology, all the resources are there online and they can learn anything they want,” he said. 
However, schools and learning institutions need to find a way around the implications of habitual reliance on technology, in particular, on the attention spans of young people and students, which many believe are becoming shorter. 
Said Dr Yen: “If (young children) are very passionate about certain topics, they can spend hours and hours dwelling on that topic, so it’s not relevant whether your attention span is eight seconds or not.” 
COMPUTATIONAL THINKING 
Nonetheless, the future of education will undoubtedly be one that will rely on technology, and Ms Hung emphasised the need to build “computational thinking” skills in the younger generation, so there is a basic understanding of how computers work. 
“Young children now can then differentiate what computers can do and what the human being can value add in the whole process. That is where the creative thinking, engineering thinking, social thinking come into the picture,” said Ms Hung. 
All of this to prepare students for their future career. 
Said Dr Yen: “The biggest change for this generation of children is that in the future, in their career, they’ll be competing with intelligences that are more than just human. They’ll be competing with intelligent machines – computers.” 
But one basic fundamental, the panel highlighted throughout the hour, was that teaching, with or without technology, should be about encouraging a journey of life-long learning. In doing so, it should focus on the importance of nurturing creativity, passion and motivation. 
“The net of education technology is about bringing the curiosity and the interest in the students about any subject that they want,” said Ms Hung. 
Watch the full episode of the panel discussion online at the Perspectives microsite . - CNA/kc
